H0.text: The age of the rock is inferred by scientists who found trilobite and brachiopod index fossils in cliffs a great distance apart from each other.

H1.text: The slope of the rock is what scientists can infer about the rocks in which the trilobite and brachiopod index fossils were found in cliffs a great distance apart.

H2.text: The density of the rock is what scientists can infer about the rocks in which trilobite and brachiopod index fossils were found a great distance apart.

H3.text: The weathering of the rock is what scientists can infer about the rocks containing the trilobite and brachiopod index fossils that were found in cliffs a great distance apart.

A4.text: Rock formations separated by great distances but containing the same index fossil species are thereby known to have both formed during the limited time that the species lived.

A5.text: The primary objective of biostratigraphy is correlation, demonstrating that a particular horizon in one geological section represents the same period of time as another horizon at a different section.
